qas.question: Why are annelids' segments like water-balloons?

answers.text: the septa enable the circular and longitudinal muscles to change the shape of individual segments

qas.question: Why are annelids' segments like helium-balloons?
What are often complete in annelids?

context: Many <b7_0>annelids<b7_0/> move by peristalsis (<a0_0><b4_0>waves of contraction and expansion that sweep along the body<b4_0/><a0_0/>), or flex the body while using parapodia to crawl or swim. In these animals <a1_0><b5_0>the septa enable the circular and longitudinal muscles to change the shape of individual segments<b5_0/><a1_0/>, by making each segment a separate fluid-filled "balloon". However, <b6_0>the septa<b6_0/> are often incomplete in annelids that are semi-sessile or that do not move by peristalsis or by movements of parapodia – for example some move by whipping movements of the body, some small marine species move by means of cilia (<a3_0>fine muscle-powered hairs<a3_0/>) and some burrowers turn their pharynges (<a2_0>throats<a2_0/>) inside out to penetrate the sea-floor and drag themselves into it.
